title: Concord
review:
I have 13+ hours on the beta.

In short, Concord is a decent game with ugly character designs and ugly costumes. The entire game feels like it was designed for controller in mind so it plays clunky on PC - plus it doesn't run super well on PC either. 

The variant system is not complete at launch: only featuring 8 out of the 16 characters. And they are weekly timegated so the whole crew building doesn't really work when you have a 12 crew system with 4 backups. 

The game is slow and clunky even with the movement buff. Only having a toggle dash is criminal on PC for keyboard. There are also no ways to turn off all these exp messages, quest pop-ups, etc. There is a lot of clutter on the screen with no setting to turn them off. The crosshair is follow-recoil and also has no way to turn it on static. 

The game is not simply not feature complete at launch and doesn't run well on PC. Not worth the $40 asking price.

title: Concord
review:
Played the beta, nothing changed to this release.

The gameplay is barely a reskin of Destiny's 10 year old multiplayer. There's not much to say about the shooting other than it's slow but sufficient and polished enough to be an F2P shooter game (oh wait).

Then you have the non-existent balance where hero picks only matter because of the gun they use if you're lucky enough the other team has something that can't avoid your shots and how many times you feed to get a really useless team buff. then you have -narrow corridor with chokepoint 1 through 6- as maps and finally, you have the 3? 5? 6? barebones and completely uninspired game modes that all play the exact same.

That's just a recipe for a game with the 100 concurrent players there are now. I'm kind of surprised no one saw this coming in the 8 years it supposedly took to develop Concord but hey, here we are.

But if you are not just in for the gameplay but for A GAME, exciting scenarios or characters, bad luck. You'll have to deal with the cast of bland characters with annoying poses, voicelines, no uniqueness or interesting abilities and the most tryhard "inclusive" roster of all that doesn't show anything inclusive AT ALL, it screams at every poorly designed element: "PLEASE GIVE US MONEY! WE ARE ON YOUR SIDE, WHATEVER IT IS".

9 skins per character that all look the same, No matchmaking (because no players), 90s QOL stuff like knowing the name and character a teammate is playing by just pressing tab, the whole match lagging when 1 person has a high ping, ZERO options to communicate besides voice, onetrick players who are pretty much encouraged to leave to get their character. I don't even know what else to put here out of so many wrong things.

This game should be in the training manual for every game developer. This is 'how to be obvious when trying to exploit modern audiences', 'how to create something that already exists, but worse', 'how to charge €40 for a game that is like the free ones but with less content'

Do yourself a favor and play ANY other game, even the hated F2P hero shooters are a million times better in almost every aspect, this has UE5 graphics which usually look good at the very least just to finish on a good note.

title: Concord
review:
I would give a neutral rating if I could. It feels like for every step where the designers clearly put a lot of love and effort, there's equal parts that feel undercooked or just straight missing. 

The game wants to have that GotG type of camaraderie with the cast but you're only given little bits of info on the characters from the little cutscenes and the lore area. I think the cast of characters could have been a fun dynamic group but they just throw a bunch of people into a room and the only premise you're given is "here you go, a bunch of people" and you only get to learn about their personalities through small conversations and, I guess, their chatter while playing the game?

I genuinely think this game would have done much better if it were a PVE game, not a PVP hero shooter. If they made something like Eidos' GotG game but as a co-op first person shooter it could have stuck out a lot more. But as it is, I don't think this game will survive very long. It was already difficult to find a game on launch day, and that will only get worse as time goes on. 

I like the feel of the gameplay, but when Destiny 2 and Overwatch are free - despite how much I don't care for those games - it's hard to justify dropping $40. I see a potential future for this game if they are able to pivot to a free model. As it is though, I requested a refund. I see the effort in the places where it shines but I didn't love the overall package enough.

title: Concord
review:
Despite what the anti-woke crowd wants you to believe, the real reason this game is failing is because it’s an uninteresting buy-to-play 5v5 hero shooter without a hook, released to a world in which the best games in the genre are free to play. The game is more akin to Lawbreakers than Overwatch, for better or worse. The visuals play a part in the sour reception of this game, but the game severely lacks a reason to keep coming back for more. 

Lack of gameplay modes is the cardinal sin. At launch, you’ve got your TDM game modes, area control game modes, and no respawn game modes. Two variations in each. 

In TDM, some characters feel near useless, particularly the tanks. They are slow, clunky, and have no actual objective to anchor themselves around. Similarly, healers are quite underpowered in this game mode as well. 

Area control modes feel like you’re playing discount Call of Duty and do not last long enough. Most games are frustrating one sided matches that end in mere minutes. 

The best game mode, the no respawn mode named Rivalry, is the least played, sometimes leading to queue times of over 7 minutes for me. In this mode, the games’s class balance and unique mechanics actually have time to shine. Too bad the tiny community isn’t supporting it. 

Deployables persisting between rounds and even character changes is a really interesting concept. The role buff system that rewards you for swapping between character roles leads to interesting, although I worry shallow, decision making when choosing characters. The currently under utilized crew system that limits your character selection also has potential. But that’s just it. This all has potential that isnt fully realized in a fully released game.  

It’s clear the Concord devs have held back content for the sake of trickle releasing it over the coming months. The problem is they failed to captivate an audience out of the gate, so the product feels incomplete and is just one more issue to throw onto the pile of disappointment. 

Concord isn’t a terrible game, but it has done very little to entice people to play it. Characters are fun to play, but lack game modes to really shine in. With a divisive visual style and a lack of a defining game mode, Concord fails to lure in an audience, and I’m not sure it can recover at this point. Multiplayer games live and die by their player base, and let’s just say there almost isn’t a player base for Concord.

title: Concord
review:
Social pandering and game budget aside, the game fundamentally just doesn't have an edge in the hero shooter space because it takes zero risks and therefore just really isn't that fun. It does nothing new and Sony played it so ridiculously safe that there's really no reason to play this over any other hero shooter.

Sure, graphically it looks great and I quite like the overall aesthetic (not the characters though) but a primary reason, if not the main reason it will fail, is because they've not tried to put their own spin or their own edge on the hero shooter genre at all. How can anyone recommend a game that's just "good" in a space that has titles that have pretty much perfected the genre at this point.

To think of all the smaller indie titles that could have been made with this budget that would have at least tried something original. Take some risks!

title: Concord
review:
Well. It's dead, and there is still money in my pocket. Oh Concord :/ It's a 6/10 at worst, and I'm genuinely gonna miss the hero mechanics in this game. Did this need to take 8 years to develop? No. It feels like a game that would have been a 7/8 about a decade ago but now is a symbol of how stagnant the industry has become. And while I can't totally disagree with that sentiment, there was a solid game here, if nothing that would set the world on fire. 

Sony and the rest need to stop spending hundreds of millions on the "Games as a service" model for every single genre of game. Game budgets are getting out of control and failure is just getting more and more expensive. We don't want you to play it safe, we want you to scale back these gargantuan rehashes of the same formulas to a level where you can actually maintain them if the player-base doesn't hit 50k concurrent players in the first week of it's life. All of the marketing and CGI promos won't save a game if the audience can get a similar experience elsewhere for cheaper. If this had shipped with any sort of substantial offline content, Sony probably wouldn't be in this mess right now.

All that being said, I wish Firewalk studios luck with whatever happens next. Regardless of how mismanaged this project was, there is genuine talent there, and it shows despite it's flaws.

title: Concord
review:
Let me preface by saying Concord is not a bad game. I went into the game with no expectations. 

I initially was drawn to this game because I am a fan of Destiny. However, I found several aspects of the game itself to be frustrating. 

PROS:
+ The graphics and presentation are phenomenal 
+ The cutscenes and character acting are superb
+ Presentation and UI are top notch
+ Movement and gunplay feel good
+ Loved the map design

CONS:
- PC performance feels spotty even with the recommended specs
- Key bindings were frequently unresponsive in combat
- No ultimates 
- Matches feel extremely short 
- Character designs are hit or miss (The guy I played as reminded me of "John Concord")

CONCLUSION:

Unless you are really itching for a new hero shooter, I'd say wait for a sale. Being online only, I'm a bit concerned as to whether this game will still have an audience several months down the road. It may, but if not, what happens is that the people who bought and support the game will have extremely long matchmaking queues and that's not very fun. I do hope this game succeeds because it is trying to do its own thing, but it just wasn't for me.

title: Concord
review:
A seemingly rushed development that resulted in a bland, quickly processed product that is more quantity than quality. It's extremely unoptimized (averaging 30-40 fps on a 7900 XTX w/ 64GB of RAM, & on NVME).

Even if you can get past the performance issues, the game has MAJOR balancing issues between its heroes. For example, Flark's gun is a complete abomination of a weapon that shoots floaty projectiles that do almost nothing for damage, whereas some other characters are running around one-tapping with their weapons. The time-to-kill ratio is VERY fast. For it to be this fast in a hero shooter, there *has* to be some modicum of health regen! Health pickups throughout maps are few and far between. Class-based systems are not emphasized ('Oh, big guy? Must be a tank. Oh, little guy with assault rifle? Must be a DPS...Wait, healer? healer?') You're kind of just left guessing about what to even do or how to strategize (Ironically, the game's training mode is quite enjoyable).

It's 2 core game modes to boot are a standard TDM and Area Control, which is basically Domination? Not bad game modes per se, just not something you would expect from this kind of game. This is something you see in a game like Rogue Company from Hi-Rez, which is completely free to play (and this is a $40-$60 title).

It's a shame because this game's design is fairly charming, almost feels like a Guardians of the Galaxy meets Overwatch type of hero shooter, but....it's riddled with technical issues that keep it from reaching its full potential.

Maybe they'll turn it around? idk, but where it currently sits from a developmental standpoint, it seems like its A LOT to ask for. Feels like I played a really early access title.

title: Concord
review:
Do not buy this game until they fix it. Even then its not worth 40 dollars in its current state. 

The main issue with this game right now is the performance. If you are lucky enough to get past the PSN login popup then you will be gifted non stop lag spikes and your computer will feel like it's on its last leg. Turn a corner and see an enemy -> game freeze -> unfreeze -> you're dead. If you're lucky it will only freeze for a second and you somehow survived. There's times it will freeze for 3 seconds and you're just waiting to be able to move again. Most likely you're dead. On top of that your whole computer will be slower while playing this game until you restart. And then on top of all that you'll most likely run into fatal crash errors every once in a while. 

If they somehow fix all that...

Overall the gameplay is decently fun, though repetitive. There are 3 playlists, one is basically TDM, the second is basically domination, and the third is their best playlist where you have to capture a bomb and planet it on a site and each player only has one life per round. It encourages teamwork and strategy which this game desperately needs. But that's it. That is all there is to this game. There's nothing worth grinding for. The cosmetics are all super basic and lazy. There are "variants" of some heroes that advertise changing how they play but they really do not.. Most likely if you were able to do random variants on heroes you wouldn't know which variant you are playing from one game to the next. They barely change anything. Some heroes could use some tweaking to make them more balanced. Most likely you'll find 3 or so characters you enjoy to play and then the rest of the roster will feel pointless to play because they just aren't as good. But player balancing can be fixed. The graphics are really good, and the UI is solid. That's about as far as it goes unfortunately.

The 40 dollar price tag is kind of insulting honestly. I'm all for buy-to-play if that's what a game wants to do but at least respect us and give us something for our money. The fact Overwatch is free and this is 40 dollars is truly insane. You get better unlocks in the free tier of the Overwatch battle pass than you do in all of Concord. Each character only has 1 skin variant that isn't a recolor and even those are MOSTLY recolors, only altering maybe a hat or a belt or something. Or they look just awful all together. I just KNOW a paid store is coming which will offer better items than what we got as a thank you for supporting this game on day one. Not to mention, looking at this current player count i'm betting this will go free-to-play within 2 months tops.

I honestly wish the game success cause when the gameplay feels good it is a good time. But I just don't understand how this game was released in this state and we had to pay for it. It truly makes no sense. Wait for this game to be free. Don't support this type of effort with your money. We as consumers deserve better from these big companies who are just serving us the bare minimum.

title: Concord
review:
As a Destiny 2 Crucible player, there are many things I like about Concord, yet I cannot in good consciousness leave a positive review due to some fundamental issues with the launch version of the game.

First, the obvious problem is a lack of players. This means when you do find a game, you will most likely find the same players. There can be no doubt that Concord has really clicked for a dozen of players, which you will find out, when your entire team of level 2 accounts blindly rushes into the open, to get absolutely destroyed in seconds. I suppose the only upside of the long queue times, is that by the time people actually get into a game, the Steam refund window will be closed.

Many reviewers have already commented on the bland character designs, which is very disappointing considering the rich worldbuilding, gorgeous environments and Bungie skyboxes. I am willing to bet my Canadian pesos that if you show a random person a picture of Teo, they would be hard pressed to tell you which game he's from. The character design is not just a failure in an aesthetic sense: given that many of the crucial roles are so visually unappealing, in random games (the only ones you can currently play due to the aforementioned lack of players) everyone will lock down the same 4 or 5 characters, which results in poor team compositions. Now I am not saying that every game needs anime waifus, but it is very important to make support and tank characters visually appealing, so that people would want to pick them. Meanwhile, players will be wondering how the hell Daw passed military qualification, lock down Star Child, and then rush into a chokepoint to get instantly obliterated.

For a $40 game, the customisation is simply not there. Each character will have 5-6 recolours, and a low-effort legendary skin that will often be somehow worse than the default outfit. For a game with such high production values, it is puzzling that the developers have spent no effort on making cosmetics unlocks visually-appealing. By comparison, if you were to spend that money on a couple of season passes for the Free-to-Play games Concord is attempting to compete with, you will end up with a bunch of outrageous, distinct outfits that probably play the sad whale song each time you score a kill.

In Concord, you can unlock variants of the 16 classes through five sets of objectives, with some variants being significantly stronger than the starting loadouts. I am definitely not a fan of this system, and it feels like a cheap way to add unlockables instead of designing a comprehensive loadout system: some guns just don't feel great, and it would be great to have some gear customisation options, instead of avoiding a character because their one weapon sucks. Yes, I get the game balance angle, but surely Concord have enough combined experience making PVP games to balance about 18 different guns!

The gunplay is mostly satisfying, some maps are quite good, and there is a lot of good game design, which makes Concord encounters interesting and enjoyable. Nonetheless, with all these issues, I just can't recommend the game and, by the time you read this review, the game will simply not have enough players to be worth saving. Also, and this can't be stressed enough, this game took 8 years to make. WHY??

title: Concord
review:
I have put in a refund request.
I would like to state the fact that there were lots of talented hard working people who contributed to this game over almost a decade and a lot of their work is great, however a lot of it also deserves criticism.

With that being said however, let's start with the gameplay of Concord. 
The base game is fun, as is basically any other arena shooter. The gun play is good, hit registration seemed fine and the levels felt well designed. The hero abilities are fine as well with some actually unique ones that do spice up the gameplay a bit. It does rely a bit on teamwork and while that does make sense, expecting randoms to cooperate with you is like expecting Sony to make good financial decisions. There are a few modes, but don't expect to play all of them because of the lack of players. 
While the basics are good and it's a pretty fun game, I don't see why anyone would pay 40$ when they can get this experience, likely more fully fledged, by playing something else. It's a fun but generic game. OK is the word that best describes it, maybe in a slight apathetic tone. It doesn't expand on anything, nothing here feels brand new, just generic fine hero shooter pvp with a Guardians of The Galaxy theme slapped on it (focus on the word "slapped" as it feels like a copy but more on that a bit later). There are variants and lots of little things that impact the gameplay that feel like slightly more fleshed out elements from other games but ultimately I was not interested enough to dive deep into them since the basic gameplay would still be basic even with a small bonus. 
 
Hero design is up next. This is obviously subjective but I am quite mixed to say the least on them. 
I liked a few of the characters such as it-Z, Lennox, Roka and Kyps but even some of these ones feel generic and look like assets bought off the market place with a coat of paint added on top. Lennox is literally alien humanoid with revolver, Roka looks like a mobile game astrounaut and Kyps is a Chat GPT prompt that reads "mannequin saul goodman cyberpunk" with the personality of my smart washing machine. 
The rest are deplorable. 
- A literal trashcan that made me burst out laughing everytime I saw it on the battlefield (and trashcan is putting it lightly that thing is bigger than some houses).
- A discord moderator with ski glasses and cleaning gloves 
- A hazard suit cleaning lady. 
- A Mukbang youtuber in military grade armor that looks like an alien turtle from afar. 
- A basic soldier with nothing special. Soldier 7 because he is not special enough to get more than that. 
And the rest that I am not mentioning because reviews have character limits. 

Live service is ironically something this game doesn't fail at (In theory). It costs 40$ but you can progress and get lots of stuff for free, there is not fortnite battle pass, no fomo, no daily log in mobile game engagement tactics. It is actually very refreshing. Props for that, but sadly it's not working out at all. The playercount is lower than my shoesize at launchday and I don't expect a huge resurgence unless it goes free to play and even then, hopium is all there is. Chasing a trend and delivering said product based on that trend 8 whole years later doesn't work, surprise surprise. 

Overall, while the graphics looks good, the artstyle is fine and the basic gameplay is generically fun, the game fails to deliver anything unique to convince people to spend single player money for something that is free everywhere else. The heroes, with a few exceptions, are simply boring or ridicolous (seriously that trashcan is just funny at this point). 
 
Not recommended unless there are major reworks to the designs with a new monetization model with something fresh. I did not even mention the story in this review as I found it to be the most generic disney rated 3+ story in history and did not bother with it (shame because they spent a lot of time and money on full on CGI cutscenes every week or something like that). 
If somehow they go F2P and convince more people to hop on, I would give it another try since the gameplay was fun. Generic fun, but still fun.

TL:DR Hopefully it goes Free to Play because the PC performance issues and lack of innovation don't put it anywhere beyond other hero shooters.

It felt mediocre, but this was intensified by the steep 50 $ CAD price tag. If it was free to play it would be an alright game, but if you're planning on releasing something like this, you're better off following the trend of free to play and relying on cosmetic profits. I wanted to give a better chance but due to steams strict refund policy I couldn't be bothered. 
The gunplay and characters seemed fun, but the lack of ultimates made each character lack a lot of flash they could have had. Game modes were scarce and closer to that of a Call of Duty play list instead of a hero shooter which was odd. TDM and Domination was all there was to it until a certain level. 
To top it off, the games performance was wildly inconsistent. Without V-Sync I experienced severe screen tearing, with it on the game ran awkwardly chunky. I have a 6800 XT and R7 5800X3D Procecessor and run any other game fine so it feels they put very little effort into PC performance testing. 
Hope they reconsider their current model to push this game into an alright spot, a bit of work and change in price could make it more approachable.

title: Concord
review:
Pros
- the game looks very nice
- characters are interesting if decisive, each have different move sets
- I was able to join active games (in brawl mode) within 2 or 3 minutes usually

Negatives
- game crashed 3 times while I played in almost 2 hours
- some characters (like the controversial bigger lady) are extremely slow, and while they have a powerful weapon with lots of ammo, are essentially just a moving target. Perhaps made for less skilled gamers (which on the surface is fine)
- not enough variation. The game modes available would get stale after a while. The cut scenes, while nicely rendered are pretty pointless not affecting the overall gameplay. It's a nice lick of paint on an entry level car

The gaming community critics are right - it should be free to play. Even in Sony squandered 100 million on it (which I somewhat wonder if this is true because it has an indie level game feel at times), they're not going to recoup their losses and it's not going to find the community it so desperately needs.

Make it free and let the modders turn it into Unreal Tournament 99 remake (which it almost feels like at times - that's a positive), and then it might save this lumbering beast of a failure.

A failure with potential, I should add. It did seem fun in places but yes I ultimately refunded because I value my $60 AUD.

Lastly I should add, I'm running it on an RTX 2060 and had to have it on lowest settings, frame rate dipped a lot - that could be on me cause I was trying to stream it for the short time I played it which took away from some CPU usage, but it is potentially fairly hardware intensive.

Hello, my name is Zety ([b]pronouns: eat/pant[/b]), and I personally do not enjoy Concord ([b]pronouns: it/flopped[/b]).
I will be comparing Concord to other, more successful hero shooters in general. I don’t enjoy the overwhelming majority of games in this genre either, so my opinion isn’t biased in favor of another. I will also be referring to Concord as "it" from here on.

[list]
[*]Many of its competitors are free, whereas it is quite expensive, especially considering the quantity and quality you get for the price.
[*]Many of its competitors look more visually appealing—environmentally, artistically, and characteristically.
[*]Many of its competitors do not require a third-party account to play.
[*]Many of its competitors aren't affiliated with the multi-billion-dollar former shell of Sony, known as Sony.
[*]Finally, many of its competitors' company members do not attack individuals in a toxic manner on X (formerly known as Twitter). It’s very unprofessional from a business or any standpoint, really, but it seems it’s becoming the norm. Please take time to work on your mental health—that goes for anyone.
[/list]

[i]On a personal note, if PlayStation Network is unavailable in roughly 121 countries compared to the 69 countries where it is available, how will LGBT+ individuals and others in these countries be able to play your game? That doesn’t seem very inclusive.[/i] ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

title: Concord
review:
TL;DR: "Concord" is a cheap, broken clone of Overwatch and TF2 with bad gameplay, uninspired characters, and outdated graphics. Don't waste your time or money.


I don't even know where to begin with this dumpster fire of a game called "Concord." First off, why on earth is it named "Concord"? I thought I was going to be playing some cool game involving the legendary Concorde plane, but no! It's just some trashy, low-effort, knock-off clone of Overwatch and Team Fortress 2. Not only does it fail at capturing the magic of either game, but it somehow manages to be worse in every possible way.

The gameplay? Clunky and broken. The characters? Bland, uninspired, and awkward rip-offs of heroes we've seen a million times before. The graphics? Laughably bad, like something from a decade ago, and not in a charming retro way—more like a "this should have been left in the garbage bin of history" way.

How this game is mostly positive on reviews is beyond me. Are people playing the same game I am? Because this thing feels like it was slapped together by a group of interns who have never played a shooter in their life. Every minute of playing "Concord" feels like a chore, and honestly, nobody should have to pay for this garbage. It's borderline robbery.

Do yourself a favor and avoid this at all costs. If you want to play a great team-based shooter, go play the games this one tried and failed to copy. "Concord" is an absolute disgrace to gaming, and the only thing it has in common with the plane is that it crashes—hard.

title: Concord
review:
After spending about 7 hours with Concord, my feelings are mixed. The emphasis on a $40 live-service model feels risky, making it a tough sell for most players. The game is short on modes, and the ones available lack inspiration. Matches often feel decided within the first minute, with few options to turn the tide. While not every hero shooter needs an Ultimate ability, Concord desperately needs a system or mechanic to make matches more engaging.

The game's approach to lore, with its supposed weekly cutscenes, is puzzling. The opening cinematic fails to make you care about or invest in any of the characters—they just exist in a world that feels like a low-budget knockoff of the MCU, complete with poor characterization and mediocre writing that attempts to mimic the MCU's humor, which never really worked to begin with. Maybe it's my ADHD talking, but reading page after page of text in the Constellation section is one of the most boring and pointless lore systems I've encountered in a game. Lore is essential for a game developer to create a framework for a character or world, but simply dumping it into the game and expecting players to understand or care about it is baffling.

Where Concord shines is in its first-person shooter gameplay. It’s fast, chaotic, and challenging. Despite some truly awful character designs, most of the characters play well and have distinct playstyles. For example, Teo appeals to those who enjoy Call of Duty-style FPS gameplay, while Kyps is all about stealth. There's a good variety in character gameplay, so most players will likely find someone they enjoy playing as.

However, the level design is lackluster. If someone asked me to name my favorite level, I wouldn’t be able to do much more than vaguely describe "the one with the crates and the glowing thing in the middle." Hero shooters succeed when you become invested not just in the characters but in the levels as well. Remember how exciting it was in Overwatch to play on a mini Las Vegas level or a deserted cowboy western level? Concord has none of that. Its levels are bland and uninspired, all feeling fundamentally the same, even if the color palettes differ. Like the characters, the levels seem to just exist without any continuity in art style or memorable locations. They all blend together, making it difficult to learn or distinguish one level from another.

Matchmaking is also concerning. While Steam data should be taken with a grain of salt, as of this writing, Concord hasn’t even reached a peak of 1,000 players. Currently, only 248 people are playing on Steam. If you’re on PC and want to play against other PC players only, you’ll face match wait times of 5-10 minutes. You have to enable crossplay to fill player slots with PS5 players, but the low player count leads to matches where everyone has poor connections. From the recent players I’ve fought, most were from the US, and since I’m based in Europe, it results in a poor performance experience.
On PC, the game’s performance is erratic. My 5900X with a 6800 XT GPU should be more than enough to run the game smoothly, but regardless of the settings, the game runs poorly, fluctuating between 150 FPS and 45 FPS within seconds. 

The game is literally causing me motion sickness. I contacted Firewalk support, and they suggested that the issue might be related to region or server problems. Being in Europe, I’m consistently matched with players from the US, which could be contributing to the game’s sluggish performance.

Concord isn’t a bad game, but its pricing is way off for the market it’s competing in. The game modes lack excitement, the characters struggle to be likable, and the level design is bland. However, it’s a solid first-person multiplayer shooter with intense and occasionally excellent combat.

Given the low player interest, I can only recommend Concord to those who are okay with spending $40 and willing to take the risks mentioned here. I will continue to play Concord for at least a week or two, just to see where the game lands both with players but also to see how the completely nonsensical story might evolve.

title: Concord

I LOVE the animations.

The character designs and costumes are for the lack of a better word amateur. They are MOSTLY bland and not distinctive enough, let alone iconic and pop. There are very few ways and different modes to actually play the game.It's overall actually very shallow in depth and story...maybe this is to be expected from season 0 of a new game like this, but everyone expects more these days. 

You can bind the arrow keys to whatever you want, but for some bizarre reason, they are HARD BOUND to just "looking". Crouch/sprint are toggle only with no options. PC players were clearly an afterthought.

The nail in the coffin? There were 100 Steam players on today and I tried matchmaking in two different modes at noon only to get timed out at 10mins. Once crossplay is on, you can get a match easy. So the only way you are going to play the game for the entire future is with PS5 players, which is fine, but not what we want. All in all I just feel bad for the hard working devs at Firewalk. I believe this project was GROSSLY mismanaged and I think most of the devs knew what was going to happen.

title: Concord
review:
Edit: Mass refunds and a shut down in under a month. Wow

TLDR: Game is a ton of fun but I can't recommend someone spend $40 on it at this moment. If the game is made free to play, or goes on a decent sale, I would recommend. 

Elephant in the room, player count. People will cope and say queues are still fast but that is only because there is 0 SBMM and no region locking WITH crossplay default enabled. Even still the no respawn mode (Rivalry) has long queues at all times, sometimes nobody queuing it at all. Speaking of Rivalry, players throwing to quickly farm XP has been an issue since launch weekend and devs have done nothing to fix it, they've been silent post launch. This makes the mode only playable with a full stack, which will lead to you 4-0'ing every match, at least in my experience. Suffice it to say the playercount is a massive issue. While the numbers are for sure better on playstation, I have serious doubts that they would even be called good, I suspect there is sub 500 players online at any given time as of 2 weeks post launch.

This leaves the other 2 respawn queues, TDM/Kill Confirmed and Domination/Hardpoint. These are both fun and I enjoy both, but there are issues with these modes. TDM matches are always far too short, the kill count should be increased from 30 to 50. Kill Confirmed is actually great, I don't have a suggested change for it. Domination and Hardpoint are both balanced around constant contesting. 2 good teams will lead to long matches where both teams struggle to garner a significant lead. A missmatched lobby will lead to quick games with score gaps of 100+. When these games go the distance they are great fun. Unfortunately due to the lack of SBMM, no doubt further impacted by the low player count, these long high quality matches are not the norm.

The core gameplay here is fantastic. Destiny PVP but way better. People compare this to Overwatch a lot but it plays nothing like that. Healing for example is very slow, so fights can end very quickly despite the generally long TTK if you don't play with your team or stand in the open. There are so many small details here that are very clever and do a lot to make basic hero shooter mechanics more engaging. A quick example is how this game does ability recharging. Every ability is unique in this regard. Some are on a timer like normal, others require kills, others pickups, and others character specific things like getting a scan with a different ability and interacting with that again. There are tons of small twists like this on the standard multiplayer hero shooter formula and almost all of them are great changes. The best way to engage with these systems is in the Rivalry mode, especially the crew bonus system that rewards swapping characters, but unfortunately Rivalry is kind of ruined by previously mentioned issues. 

People really don't like the character designs. I'm probably 50/50 like/hate on the roster. I really like some of the character designs like Kyps and Jabali, but then there are huge stinkers like Daw and Bazz (although when you unlock different glasses for Bazz she is way better IMO). There is 0 sex appeal here, which I think is what has most people upset even though they would never admit it. Whether or not this matters a ton is is up to you. For me this is not a major issue, I play these kind of games for the gameplay and if it looked like Roblox with fancy lighting and effects I wouldn't really care. Aside from character models the game looks very good IMO. 

Tech wise I've only had some infrequent crashing and small bugs. I am on a 4070ti Super with an AMD 7800x3D though so I can't really comment on performance. Runs good for me, might not on a worse setup.

Im a Sci Fi guy, big on Star Wars pre Disney and I love Mass Effect. This games lore/world has a lot to like. You can read about an astonishing amount of things in the "Galactic Guide", essentially this games prettier version of the mass effect codex. Unfortunately there is no voice acting here so it is a lot of reading. Some sneak peeks here: The entire galaxy is slowly being consumed by something called the tempest, the pseudo galaxy government known as the guild is consuming the finite resources without having a plan for when they run out, and most of the food people eat are giant squid like creatures from another planet doused in grounded up egg goo that makes it taste good. People dismiss this mode, but I think its a great addition and its clear that a lot of effort has been put into this. Were this game to have a long lifespan (which I seriously doubt at this point) there would be so many cool ways for the story to go. You can also read this while you are in queue which is very nice.

There are also the weekly "vignettes" but both featured so far were also in the beta so this has been extremely underwhelming as of now. 

With the $40 price tag some promises were made and there was also some automatic expectations. I have been overall disappointed with the value for my money when it comes to this. One thing that was promised thanks to the price tag was no paid battle pass, which is true come launch. Progression in this game is based on your account level and individual character level. Both account and character levels earn you separate rewards. Unfortunately a lot of the rewards you will be earning here are underwhelming. Trinkets seen as battle pass filler in other games still make their appearance here despite the lack of battlepass. Here they serve as progression filler so they can tell you there is a reward in the next few levels when all it ends up being is a weapon charm you probably won't even bother to equip. There are also a TON of re-colours.

Furthermore a lot of the "big" rewards you will eventually earn like legendary skins kind of suck. Like the character designs, legendary skins are probably 50/50 good/bad. Emari's is great and fixes a character who I don't like the regular look of. Meanwhile Jabali's biggest change is some horns on his hat. Despite some of these underwhelming rewards levelling also takes a SIGNIFICANT amount of time. With 60 hours in the game as of writing (5 or so being afk or accidentally left on) I still do not have a single character at level 20, and multiple still not at level 10. My account level is only just 50, with the hardest achievement in the game being to reach account level 100. I have only seen one of these legendary skins in the wild during a match. Progression could be 2x as fast and I would still probably think its a bit slow, but that would be a great improvement.

There is a cosmetic shop coming with the season 1 patch scheduled for October (although we will see how this schedule holds given the games launch), and I will be very upset if a bunch of way cooler skins are added with it and nothing else is added to the games current progression.

I don't regret buying the game, I expected to only get 2 months or so out of it as casual shooter game I could play on the side, but I didn't think the numbers would be THIS bad. I can't recommend a purchase in its current state unless devs come out with some sort of action plan. If it ever does go free or on a deep sale I highly recommend, because the actual game that is here is very good.

title: Concord
review:
This is a very bare bones review during the early access period.

Concord has the foundations of a great arena based hero shooter, combining elements of Destiny 1 PVP and Overwatch. However right now there appears to be serious problems with matchmaking here in the EU. It's hard to tell the exact cause but judging by the overly long wait times (1-2 mins minimum) and the fact that my ping is showing as low compared to everyone else in the lobbies, I'd place a bet in saying not only is the player base extremely low, but that the majority are based on NA servers.

I'm hoping that upon full release later today a big wave of players will help iron out these matchmaking problems as I really just want to give the game a fair shot after I had a good amount of fun with the Beta. Here's hoping that others give the game a chance and in doing so creates a better experience for all of us currently facing matchmaking and latency issues.

title: Concord
review:
While the rough core of the game isnt bad and there is a semblence of a stable foundation, the game doesnt innovate and even is missing critical systems needed for a multiplayer game. In this rough shape and at this price, the game has a serious problem to get the attention of potentional players as its presentation is at best lukewarm and the gameplay lacks all common improvements present in the gaming scene in the past years. Due to various issues listed bellow, I cannot recommend this game at this current state and price. I personally will keep playing the game, but with these issues, I cannot recommend it.

[b]Gameplay[/b] 
The core of the gameplay is present and if this is your first game of this type, it may feel fresh at first, but it is lacking larger and smaller QoL improvements. One of them is partial weapon reloads, there are too many instances where you can accidentaly interrupt the realoding animation and once you want to resume it, it begin from the start. A smaller QoL feature that is missing is Assist counting as kills, this is needed in high latency lobbies. The game gas a weird long time to kill, which I am personaly not fan of.

[b]In-game communication[/b] 
The game has a basic pinging system and an option to opt-in into voice chat at the start of the match and that is it. The game lacks a communication wheel to say simple commands to your team like "Group up", "I need healing" or even "Thank you". Chat is not present at all. This team oriented game has almost no ways how to communicate as a team.

[b]Crew system[/b]
I feel this system is at the core the cause of the character balance issues. Some characters are strong from the get go and these feel good to play. But other you first need to apply bonuses by playing different characters and by that time in the match, you have no assurance that the actual character you want to play isnt already taken (and there is no way to tell other players you want to switc to said character). Basicaly if you wan to play a strong character, you do not need to use the crew system. If you want to play a weaker character, you first need to switch trough various different characters to make the one you want to play less bad and you will still play worse than the good characters.

[b]Game modes[/b]
The game has 3 playlists, Brawl, Overrun and Rivarly.
Brawl consist of TDM and TDM+ (kill confirmed)
Overrun consist of Capture the zones, and capture the moving zone
Rivalry is a no respawn gamemode, but I never got to play it.

Brawl and Overrun plays the same and most people ignore the objectives in Overrun as there is no incentive from the game to play objectives. There is no Capture the Flag, no Paylod, no Push, no PvE, no Deathmatch.

[b] Multiplayer and queue times[/b] 
About a week has passed since the release of the game and depending on the time of day, you may get a quick queue time in about 30 seconds, but if you are on PC and in the EU, you may experience queue times of 2 - 3 minutes even for the most played "Brawl" playlist. And if you get into a match, be prepared to be places into a high latency lobby. I wasnt able to get into "Rivalry" playlist as the queue times went above 6 minutes and I gave up.

[b]Progression and unlocks[/b]
Most progression objectives are a variation of number of kills, assist, damage done, rounds played, rounds won. The progression system has minimal teamwork oriented objectives and so far none related to capturing a zone or any tied more to the gamemodes.

The game doesnt show you what item you unlock at what level, it only shows what is the current item to be unlocked, but you have no idea if the next one is something """interesting""" or another side bar color.

[b] Characters (gameplay wise)[/b] 
16 characters and a lot of them feels unbalanced. You get strong characters that can stand on their own like Lennox and Haymar, and on the other end of the spectrum you get Jabali with his BB gun. The overall issue is that some characters have a really low damage output and if you are in a high latency lobby and experiencing high ping and lost packets, playing those characters is misery.

[b]Characters (lore wise)[/b] 
The game is unable to sell the personas of the characters to the players. There is no banter between characters at the start of the match that would tell you what the relation between each character is. So if you are not drawn in by the looks of the characters, there isnt much else to know about them. The only info you get is an entry which you get by leveling a character to level 3, but as of now, it only talks about their backstory.

[b]Characters (visualy)[/b]
Most of the characters designs feels like they need more iterations befoure they could be considered good. Some designs are just too much, like the design of Bazz would benefit from a streamlining.

[b]Custom games[/b] 
There is no option to host your own lobby.

[b]Lore[/b] 
One of the selling point of the game is its lore and how it is presented in the Galactic Guide. While the visual presentation is nice in a form of a galactic map, the game does a very poor job of connecting said lore to the gameplay. The lore set up the freegunners as oponnents to the Guild, but there is no hint of that in the gameplay at all as all is freegunners fighting each other.
The game has [b]vignetters (CGI shorts)[/b] which plays at the start of the game, but only the newest one plays and otherwise they are not present in the game at all and you need to do your own homework to find them.
There are also [b]Freegunners adventtures shorts (animated shorts)[/b] which are not in the game, there is no mention of them in the game and you need to be lucky to find them.

Good game. Fun mechanics, beautiful graphics, great music and sound. I love the Disney-like cutscenes and art style, it immediately feels warm and familiar. No bugs to be seen, very surprising for a new game. The theme is Guardians of the Galaxy meets Overwatch, but the gameplay is fresh and interesting. I love the timed racing mode, it reminds me of Mirror's Edge parkour. More games should have skill trials like this. 

I'm sad to hear about Concord's early end. I guess people don't spend much money up front on multiplayer games since so many are F2P now. I don't blame anyone for saving money, but I guess we're stuck with loot boxes and virtual currencies forever. I hope Concord comes back with a F2P makeover so more people can see how fun it is.

title: Concord
review:
Well I'd been playing this game nightly ever since it released, trying to earn the achievements and improve my skills with all the characters, only to come home and find out that Sony has given up on Concord three weeks in, as if it's failure wasn't largely their fault. This isn't the first time a niche FPS I like has bit the dust, see Hyperscape and the entire Titanfall franchise, but this one hurts a little more because this was the first Hero Shooter I ever really liked playing.

The failure of Concord comes down to a lot of intersecting factors but it is nevertheless shocking to see a game this feature complete with this much effort and lore put into it that is just gone, after less than 3 weeks. The announcement says they are exploring other options, like maybe a F2P relaunch, and I dearly hope that's true, but I'm not holding my breath. If more people had been willing to overlook the superficial deficiencies of this game I feel like a very interesting PVP sandbox would have emerged. Rivalry is one of the most interesting and well thought out gamemodes I have ever played in this type of shooter.

At the end of the day, Concord's failure to attract an audience can likely be attributed to the fact that in modern gaming, games are not given a chance to breathe, and must succeed immediately, combined with poor marketing and the fact that the FPS genre is one of the most impenetrable markets in gaming. Just about every permutation has a central pillar that any other challengers will always be in the shadow of. Cod,Overwatch,Fortnite,Apex, they have all locked down their parcels of land and it's been basically impossible for anything else to break out. The only thing that really sets Concord apart from the rest of the FPS graveyard at this point is the gap between the quality of this game and the magnitude of it's failure, which is surpassed maybe only by Titanfall 2, arguably the best example of a 10/10 FPS flop.

Someday I hope Concord returns and I can play it again, and that it finds an audience when it does. Until then, all I'll have are the experiences I had playing it. If and when it does come back, if you bothered to read this review for whatever reason, I hope you give it a shot. It might surprise you.

title: Concord
review:
Leaving a review because I think the game and its devs are receiving a disproportionate amount of hate.
[list]
	[*][b]Price[/b]: Single price tag and you can unlock all content including post-launch content. A lot of people understandably don't like that it's not F2P like other live service games. However, this way you're not getting pushed microtransactions via predatory tactics (e.g. P2W, loot box gambling and battle pass FOMO). It's worth considering on a sale if you find the price too steep.
	[*][b]First impressions[/b]: This game was written off by people ever since its reveal, it looked derivative, like a Guardians-themed Overwatch clone. It's a superficial judgement that I initially shared as well. I ended up trying the game and enjoyed it, but I'd imagine the internet echo chamber is making it difficult for others to do the same.
	[*][b]Characters[/b]: A common complaint is that the character designs are uninspiring and boring. I understand they're supposed to be a ragtag team of everyday people from the Concord universe, but I agree. They could've expanded on this with the character skins, but it's just comprised of basic palette swaps. This directly inhibits sense of progression as well, because they're rewarding you with these underwhelming skins.
	[*][b]Pronouns[/b]: The character selection screen includes pronouns for each character. A lot of people are [i]genuinely [/i]aggravated by this. It's not even prominently displayed - I didn't even notice the text until I saw all the comments about it.
	[*][b]Performance[/b]: It's pretty badly optimised. To get a stable framerate, I'm playing on DLSS Ultra Performance preset with everything set to low. It's crashed a couple times without any error messages, but is fortunately quite rare. There have been some performance patches already, but I expect it will take a while to fully iron things out.
	[*][b]Community feedback[/b]:  The devs listen to players; they addressed a lot of major issues reported in the beta by launch, which were about a month apart.
	[*][b]Match length[/b]: The matches are short and don't drag on, I'd say no more than 10 minutes. 
	[*][b]Gameplay[/b]: Gunplay is solid. Abilities are simple to grasp and roles don't feel restrictive - healers can hold their own. I still don't have a main because I find each hero is fun enough to swap between, depending on the situation. There are no ultimates, probably to maintain pacing and avoid major game swings with a click of a button.
	[*][b]Strategy[/b]:[b] [/b]There's some strategy sprinkled in with the idea of variants, which encourages building your own roster with different passives, and switching between roles in-game to stack the relevant crew bonuses you'd need.
	[*][b]Audio[/b]: Very well done - SFX is satisfying and I can easily pinpoint where enemies are spatially (which is great if I could actually hit them afterwards)
	[*][b]Release date[/b]: This shared a release date with Black Myth, one of the most anticipated games of the year. This may have contributed to the lower numbers, but I'm not sure how much of a difference it would've actually made.
	[*][b]PSN account[/b]: It requires a PSN account, which isn't available everywhere. Some people don't trust Sony with their data or hate having to make another account. We're also coming right off the back of the Helldivers 2 controversy around this topic, which may have left a sour taste in people's mouths.
	[*][b]Crossplay[/b]: It's enabled by default and[b] should stay on[/b] for fast matchmaking. There aren't many PC players (there are dozens of us... dozens!)
[/list]


[b]Conclusion[/b]
The core gameplay is solid. The pricing method is a healthy thing for consumers. The devs are trying new things with a new IP - they seem like they have good intentions and listen to community feedback. There are performance issues on launch, but it looks it's currently being addressed.


There's a strange herd mentality praying for Concord's downfall, which feels unjustified because the studio hasn't really done anything [i]wrong[/i]. I hope it manages to survive, because I think this will ultimately hurt the kind of games we'll see in the future if it doesn't.

title: Concord

where to start?

performance is so bad, after the first hour of playing your PC struggles to keep up.  if you're lucky enough to not crash, you'll just constantly freeze for 1-3 seconds during gunfights. progression is a joke.  most of the stuff you unlock in the game is just re-colors.  there are only 2 unique "legendary" skins IMO.

no innovation on game modes.  rivalry mode is the most fun for me and the other 2 game modes are just boring

scratching my head on how it took 8 years to make this game

firewalk at this point should just put out thousands of free keys to the game on their twitter because after a week this game is going to be fully dead, it won't even make it to season 1.  or do a couple free to play weekends leading up to season 1

even if the game goes free to play at this point, I don't think there's any redemption here, sadly
